comments.commentBody: Big win for RBNY, albeit against a wan LA performance. But Rost mad a couple of key first half saves. Marquez' pass to Henry was sublime for the second, and clinching, goal. This may be a first round playoff preview, with Don Garber dreaming that it might be a final, sigh.

And we know from past history that Mr. Dell's advice is gold. His 1997 advise to Apple was a true gem:

http://news.cnet.com/2100-1001-203937.html
If you were selecting your five favorite cheeses for a cheese board, what would they be and why?
What do you think are the top cheese shops in the US?

1. Buying good cheese can be very costly at the market. So, what kind of cheese do you recommend stocking in my pantry? I am making a lot of Italian dishes right now.

2. Which cheese goes best with white wine? Which cheese goes best with red wine?

3. Also, when SHOULDN'T you eat the rind? haha
Do you really like being called FloFab?  In an otherwise elegant column, this moniker just seems barbarous (barbar?)

Let's assume writer #1 is female. Should she be grateful her brother doesn't insist she cover her hair or face while in public? If male, should he be grateful his brother not insist he wear a beard, or shave, or whatever the religious one dictates?

A wise friend who was seriously Jewish explained to me that he didn't keep kosher because he couldn't see how his choice of food had anything to do with morality.

The Muslim brother is not preparing his children for living in America where people (ideally) do not impose their own religious compulsions on others; we are all free to practice religion as we see fit, and all entitled to be free from others' religious beliefs. This ideal is not always in evidence, but it should be.

Finally why do just about all the commenters here call enjoying wine with a meal "drinking?" In my Italian family wine is considered an honored component of a meal, as are the anitpasto and the sauce. In Catholic and Episcopal religious services, wine is consumed. The Muslim brother should be teaching his children tolerance rather than bigotry.
MIchele had her 15 mins. And in an instant, it's all over.
She's at about 3 percent in the polls.  What a joke.
Why is the media continuing to cover this woman?
'Mr. Maloney “is just some dude who drilled oil wells, made a lot of money and decided he wanted to be governor.' substitute that for Mr. Perry
Wowzie!  Just what we need in the Democratic Party--another Blue Dog.  NOT!

How interesting that #7 is doing EXACTLY what he is accusing dems of doing. We know that Repubs are not going to create jobs bc we had 8 yrs of Bush that got us into this mess. Why are you all so blind to that fact. Obama inherited the whole mess from W. and has done an excellent job with what he has to work with. i.e., republicans who will not cooperate or play by the rules. The main repub. goal now is too make sure to limit voting rights for as many dems i.e., young, poor, black, as possible. Republicans do not have a moral fiber amongst the lot of em.

As far as an out-of-stater can tell, this was a close race, dominated by local issues, in which neither candidate had much use for Obama.  He lost West Virginia last time, and I'll be floored if he wins there next year.

"All politics is local." - Tip O'Neill

I'm neither excited nor thrilled either, and I'm a resident. Politics shouldn't be about emotion. If anything calls for clear, logical decision-making, it's voting. I'm glad that a Democrat won. I'm not a Democrat. I'm glad because the Republican party is owned by the corporate machine, and is concerned only with high dividends. Some say they, the Republiicans, are "focused" on destroying the middle class. That's incorrect. They are, and I don't mind repeating myself, focused on high profits. Lowering labor cost is just one way to maximize profits, but it can pay off big for a company when it wins a concession. Recent anti-trade union behavior of some state governments following Republican routs in blue territory is illustrative of this mindset. They went to labor to balance their books after decades of government waste and deal making. That the middle class is evaporating is of little consequence to the corporation, collateral damage.

They have replaced men with robots, and moved jobs offshore. Not in order to survive, but thrive, with record profits. Now they want the last drop from the veins of labor. We have literally built the country with our labor while our lifestyle has declined.
Republicans are out to kill our Medicare. Their cruelty and selfishness will cost the party dearly.

16.Punnisher . "I see local people all the time who support the Republican party and their financial situation is not even close to mine"...me too. I can't believe the level of deception in this country. It is hard for someone like myself, born in Europe, to live here, and witness this phenomenon. It is the legacy and result of 50 plus years of pop culture that supports this reactionary propaganda. American pop culture has lowered the educational requirement of a very large segment of the general population, where being "uninformed" is popular. American movies offer a striking example of this. 50 years ago Hollywood made movies that were literate, and that a typical educated afult person could comprehend. These movies are almost unintelligible to these same Republicans you mention who make less money than you, and vote Republican. The education of the general population was given in the public school systems was a lot higher 50 + years ago than it is today. The fact is theses movies from 50 + years ago were intelligible to the general population of America 50+ years ago! What does that tell you it is ! Maybe you people cant see this cause you live in it..but I do...and Im telling you think about what I am telling you

Its a shame Shelly Capito didn't run. Then the GOP would be in WV's executive.

Of course both candidates are going to oppose the EPA and support coal. There are coal burning power plants that provide power for the entire state and many throughout the mid-west, as well as coal mines in the entire state. Imagine what the state's "median-income" you so frequently mention would be like without these jobs? Plus add increased input costs for electricity (used in the production of everything!) caused by the EPA, and more jobs are lost. While something other than mining would be a great option for many people, those jobs do pay 40-50k per year with benefits. Its hard to fault the state's leaders for fighting the EPA's regulations when it will make them even more dependent on federal money!

And in terms of the woman's response "being wrong with the electorate," you are off point. Yeah, people should be more informed, but frankly is it worth the opportunity cost of knowing the candidates? They are blatantly contradictory, their ads mention nothing about their policy positions, and acquiring that information isn't worth it for many people. In the end, you have the opportunity cost (ie your time) learning all of that stuff, the cost of going to the poles, waiting, etc. to vote in an election that you that your vote will NEVER be decisive. As academics have pointed out for ages, voting is an irrational behavior.

The add campaign, which accused the candidate of wanting to take away social benefits, while even if untrue, probably signaled the candidate's general philosophy. That policy may have never happened, but it still allowed the woman to make an informed decision about her philosophical views vs. the candidate.
The only wat a Republican wins is if the GOP motivates their base. Mitt Romney= ZERO MOTIVATION!!!! Need I say more?

A couple of questions for No. 3 Don and others who are on his side:

- Who, in American history, "fixed the economy" starting from an early, deep, global depression, in one term while there were two inherited wars going on at the same time? Or, for that matter, in two terms? Which great American leader did something magical like this?

- Which American president "fixed" anything with an opposition in power in Congress which refused to support anything the president wanted to do, and many of whose members wouldn't compromise even to the extent of voting to save the country from defaulting on its debt? Which American prisident did this magical thing?

- Since your stated reasons for lambasting President Obama are so flimsy they wouldn't block the light of a candle a football field away, why don't you just get down to bone fact and admit why you don't like President Obama?
So the message is what "I won't mess with you so I can have your vote but I'll take it out of your children and grand children's hide'?

Solyndra will be the gift that keeps on giving to the Republicans.

We have the embarrassing Biden tape and the Obama walk-through. We have the e-mails, vested interest, and big donor payoffs...all gambling away (again) with the taxpayers' money.

Solyndra is different than the long list of bankrupt companies that were cursed by the Obama administration. The fingerprints are all over the scene of this crime, where Obama decided (again) to ignore the checks/balances that protect Americans, and took the money and ran.

"It's important because these (1000+ Solyndra) jobs are going to be permanent jobs. These are the jobs of the future. These are the green jobs. These are the jobs that won't be exported. These are the jobs that are going to define the 21st Century and the jobs that are going to allow America to compete and to lead like we did in the 20th Century." ---VP Joe Biden, Sept 4, 2009

Stupidity and Stubborness is a bad combo for leadership or anything, especially during the "worst financial crisis since" blah blah blah. These jobs "won't be exported" because they're non-existent. This is Chicago shell-game politics with no trace and no way of us ever getting our 1/2Billion$ back. The public is on to the "green jobs" "climate change" con game.

Mets tickets have been priced dynamically for years. First by the guys who stood under the 7 train at Roosevelt Avenue, then by StubHub. Mets are trying it themselves, after seeing success in San Francisco and elsewhere. Now it will take a winning team to raise ticket prices accordingly. Sounds familiar, the Wilpons  expecting unreasonable returns? Tell that to Judge Rakoff ...

I would like to apologize to the Yankee Universe for my lack of confidence in A.J. Burnett tonight. My sense of doom was based on Burnett's history. Please accept my apology and do not take my pinstripes away from me.
